meanings.definition: To estimate or offer a price that is lower than the actual value.
meanings.sent1: The seller lowballed the cost of the old book.
meanings.sent2: He always lowballs his offers to get a better deal.
meanings.sent3: The student lowballed the number of pages in his report, hoping the teacher wouldn't notice.
meanings.sent4: The detective lowballed the suspect's alibi, suspecting foul play.
meanings.sent5: The mechanic lowballed the repair cost, but the final bill was much higher.

meanings.definition: To intentionally underestimate or undervalue something.
meanings.sent1: She lowballed her own abilities and missed out on opportunities.
meanings.sent2: The company lowballed the value of the antique vase at the auction.
meanings.sent3: The chef lowballed the taste of his new dish, but it turned out to be a hit.
meanings.sent4: The explorer lowballed the beauty of the hidden waterfall in the jungle.
meanings.sent5: The artist lowballed the worth of her painting, not realizing its true value.

meanings.definition: To give a deliberately low estimate or bid.
meanings.sent1: The contractor lowballed the project cost to win the bid.
meanings.sent2: They always lowball their offers to secure the deal.
meanings.sent3: The comedian lowballed the number of laughs he would get, but the audience loved his jokes.
meanings.sent4: The politician lowballed the support he would receive, but the turnout was overwhelming.
meanings.sent5: The team lowballed their score prediction, but they ended up winning by a large margin.
